area_name: Emerald Lake - Multipitch from the ground up

content.description: Approach: (3 minutes) Walk diagonally across the first scree cone, following a faint trail, to reach the first ledge system. Carefully scramble to the right along the ledge, past a clump of trees and then farther along past a lone tree, to reach the first station with 2 bolt hangers. Pitch 1 (5.6, 8 bolts, 70m) Climb up and left, clipping the 1st bolt of Rags to Riches route and then veer off to the right and up towards another bolt. Continue following bolts, trending right and up, until you reach a 2 bolt belay on a ledge. Pitch 2 (5.8, 6 bolts, 28m) Climb up through the 5.8 crux of the route, traverse out right, and then keep following the bolts, trending up and right to a 2 bolt belay station. Pitch 3 (5.8, 8 bolts, 52m) Keep trending right and up, until you reach the tree at the top! Sling the tree if you like. But continue past the tree to one more bolt and then a 2 bolt belay station. From here, you can scramble up through the forest to the Upper Amphitheatre Wall! Fun, fun fun! :D Descent: Traverse to the right through the trees until you find a set of rap rings. This station will let you rappel down the "Date Night" route. OR continue traversing to the right to reach the Lunch Log and then take the "Exit Date" route to reach the top of the ridge for a "walk off" down the ridge towards the Highway, and then around to the base of the cliff and walk to the parking lot. Bolted. Regular hangers at stations 1, 2 and 3!

4 bolts plus gear. 20m. head up to the right of the roof, a cam can be placed at the first ledge and a nut to protect the crux is near the top. Rings at the top to the right, rope can be tricky to pull.



You will walk south from the parking lot through the trees up the scree slope. Start just right of the roof. 

Bolts plus gear

climbs.name: Buyer Beware
climbs.fa: Morgan Fines, Nathan Shenton, Brian Crump, David Relkoff, Sept 2018

content.description: Approach: (5 minutes) Walk diagonally across the first scree cone, following a faint trail, to reach the cliff and then head further up left along the cliff, about 40m past the small wooden bench. Pitch 1 (5.9, 6 bolts, 16m) This is the crux! Delicate moves on clean rock will get you up past 6 bolts to a pair of ring bolts at the station. Pitch 2 (5.9, 9 bolts, 21m) This is the pitch to beware of ... This pitch has a bouldery start on great rock but moves up and left into a section of easier, but very chossy, terrain. Take care through this section and climb up to a pair of rings bolts on a nice roomy ledge. Pitch 3 (5.9, 8 bolts, 27m) The money pitch! Great rock up past 8 bolts to an overhang. Head up to the overhang and then traverse left, underneath it over to another pair of rings bolts. The overhang protects this belay station from rock fall from above. Pitch 4 (5.4, 3 bolts, 24m) Easy and fun top out pitch to the big treed ledge. There is some small loose rock on this easy angle pitch, good thing the belayer can hide away underneath that overhang! Pitch 5 (TBD) Descent: Rappel the route with a single 60m rope. Bolted. Rap Hangers at each station as you rappel the route to get back down.

Approach: (6 minutes) Walk along the old road to the scree cone underneath the orange corner crack. Take a faint trail up the left side of the scree cone to the cliff and follow the cliff up to the big corner. See photo ... blue line (h) on photo. Pitch 1 (5.6, 30m) Follow the corner system up and left around the overhang above the start, to a 2 bolt anchor at the top of the first pitch. Pitch 2 The pitch above has not (to my knowledge) been climbed yet, but it looks a bit loose and sketchy in my opinion ... Descent: Rappel the single pitch back down to the ground. The anchor bolts are just regular hangers, so you may need to leave a carabiner or piece of cord behind if there isn't something already there. Gear. Nuts and Cams, mostly cams ...

Approach: (6 minutes) Walk along the old road to the scree cone underneath the orange corner crack. Take a faint trail up the left side of the scree cone to the cliff and follow the cliff up to the climb. See photo ... yellow line (g) on photo. Pitch 1 (5.10a, 11 bolts, 30m) Start a few meters to the right of Date Night, just a few meters left of the orange corner crack. Follow the bolts up the face and eventually traverse left towards the 1st belay station of Date Night. This is a slightly easier 1st pitch alternate to the Date Night route. Bolted. Rap Hangers at each station as you rappel the route to get back down.

Approach: (6 minutes) Walk along the old road to the scree cone underneath the orange corner crack. Take a faint trail up the left side of the scree cone to the cliff and follow the cliff up to the climb. See photo ... orange line on photo. Pitch 1 (5.10d, 8 bolts, 30m) Climb out of the scoop on the slight overhang/corner over the bulge and follow the bolts up to the ring bolt belay station. Pitch 2 (5.10c, 6 bolts, 22m) Straight on up to the next ring bolt belay. Pitch 3 (5.10b, 5 bolts, 20m) Make delicate airy moves off the anchor into good holds with some exposure. Crest the lip and traverse right along a loose ledge to the two bolt anchor. Tread carefully on the ledge ... save your belayer from a rock shower!  Pitch 4 (5.6, 4 bolts, 28m) Continue up through easy terrain to the Lunch Log! Descent: From the Lunch Log, continue walking to the right, through the trees until you reach the fixed lines. Rappel, traverse, rappel, traverse, rappel, and you’re down! We are planning to do some more work on this to make it even more user-friendly and may at some point swap out the fixed ropes for steel cable like a via ferrata line … stay tuned … Alternate Descent: On pitch 3, once you crest up and over onto the big ledge, locate the rap rings that are slightly up and left. Belay your partner up to here and then you can rappel down! A single 70m rope will get you exactly down to the top of pitch 1 and then one more rappel to the ground. With a single 60m rope, you'll need to do three rappels to reach the ground. Bolted. Rap Hangers at each station as you rappel the route to get back down.

Approach: (3 minutes) Walk diagonally across the first scree cone, following a faint trail, to reach the cliff and then head further up left along the cliff to a small wooden bench which is at the base of the route. Pitch 1 (5.6, 6 bolts, 33m) Follow the low angle ramp up and right. Circle out right around the tree between bolts 1 and 2. You will want to adjust how your rope runs over the trees. Continue up and right through the chimney to the treed ledge above. The two bolt station to the right marks the start of pitch 2. Pitch 2 (5.10a, 11 bolts, 53m) The climbing line meanders a little left and a little right of the bolt line at times to find the line of least resistance and solid rock, but you generally head straight up to the anchors above. Pitch 3 (5.9, 14 bolts, 55m) Step up and right to the first bolt. Then follow the bolts over good rock up and left over the bulge. From here trend up and right around an airy corner. Rings for the variant will be about 15 feet off to your right at about bolt 12, keep going up to the rings above. Using long runners to manage rope drag on this pitch is advised. Pitch 3a (5.9, 10 bolts, 45m) Climb a short step just right of the belay to get on a large ledge system. Follow this right about 15m. Head up following the bolts. The second half of this pitch is pretty loose. From the rings at the top of this pitch you can climb a short pitch up and left to reach the pitch 3 station. Pitch 4 (5.9, 6 bolts, slings, 25m) From the rings head straight up to the obvious ledge above, slinging a tree or two on the way. The real climbing for the pitch starts about 3m left at a large pine growing right next to the face. This spot makes a nice belay if you want to sling the tree. Head straight up and a little left over the bulge to find surprisingly technical slab above. Descent: Rappel the standard route (not the alternate P3) with two 60m ropes OR from the ledge system just above the rings at the top of P3 traverse the right to find the anchors for the top of Rags to Riches and rap with a single 60m rope. Stay roped in for the traverse. The terrain is not technical but it is easy to slip on the vegetation and pine needles in climbing shoes and a fall would be disastrous OR from the top of P2 head left up the ledge system to gain the anchors at the top of P4 of Family Jewels. From there you can rappel Family Jewels with a 60m rope. Be sure to tie knots in the ends of your rope!  Bolted. Rap Hangers at each station as you rappel the route to get back down.

Approach: (3 minutes) Walk diagonally across the first scree cone, following a faint trail, to reach the cliff and then head further up left along the cliff to a small wooden bench which is at the base of the route. Pitch 1 (5.10b, 5 bolts, 20m) A couple of bouldery moves between bolts 1 and 3 will get you over the bulge. From there trendy up and right on easier ground (5.7) to gain the ledge and the belay. Pitch 1a (green line) (5.5, 4 bolts, 20m) Follow the low angle ramp up and right. Circle out right around the tree between bolts 1 and 2. You will want to adjust how your rope runs over the tree. At around 16m there will be an obvious blocky dihedral on your left. Follow this feature up to reach the belay ledge. Pitch 2 (5.7, 3 bolts, 10m) Climb up through the vertical band of rock directly above the belay to another station. Pitches 1 and 2 can be combined together into a 30m pitch if you feel comfortable doing so. Pitch 3 (5.8, 8 bolts, 30m) Follow bolts up and left through a system of ledges and then onto the slab, avoiding the loose rock on the left, to a belay on the right side of the alcove above. Pitch 4 (5.7, 5 bolts, 27m) Climb up just right of the anchor. Follow the bolts through the initial 5.8 difficulties to easier ground above. Then carefully step up through some loose low angle rock and debris to reach the anchor and have a sandwich on the giant comfy ledge. Pitch 5 (5.9, 9 bolts. 37m) Just left of the belay a couple of hard moves will get you off the ledge and into easier jug pulling above. Don’t stop at the first set of rings just carry on up and slightly left to the big ledge above. Descent: Rappel the route with a single 60m rope. Pitch 5 is more than 30m and you will need to use the intermediate station to rap it with a single 60m rope. (A 70m rope lets you bypass this intermediate station). NOTE: Be sure to tie knots in the ends of your rope and wear a helmet! Bolted. Rap Hangers at each station as you rappel the route to get back down.

20m One pitch with 8 bolts starts at the orange rock under the roof. The orange rock is slick and polished, with interesting pockets up to the crux.  The crux is well protected as you make the moves out of the roof. After the roof, you will go up towards the apex of the rock. The anchor is just over the ledge. Be cautious of loose blocks near the top.



The start is near the bottom of the v-shaped cliff baned to the southeast of the main wall. You will walk south from the parking lot through the trees and up the scree slope to access this area. 

8 Bolts

1st pitch: 12 bolts, 34m2nd pitch: 11 bolts, 32m Approach: (6 minutes) Walk along the old road to the scree cone underneath the orange corner crack. Take a faint trail up the left side of the scree cone to the cliff and follow the cliff up to the climb.  Start 10m left of date night on ledge (20m left of the orange corner) Shiny Bolts!
Rappel the route with a 70m rope!!
Or ... traverse from 2nd station of Ghosted over to Date Night and rap Date Night with a 60m rope.

Approach: (5 minutes) Walk down the old highway past the seasonal waterfall and past the top rope crag until you are at the beginning of the large scree/talus slope at the base of the wall. Find the first bolt at the bottom left corner of that slope. The first belay is no more than 15m from the road. Pitch 1 (5.5, 3 bolts, 17m) Head up towards the obvious ledge with a large tree. Note: this pitch is possible to bypass by scrambling the ledge to the left of the bolts. Pitch 2 (5.6, 3 bolts, 20m) Straight forward to the small ledge above. Anchor has a shut and an old carabiner for descending. Pitch 3 (5.10a, 5 bolts, 16m) Head up to the small but obvious roof. Step delicately onto the slab portion above. Anchors on the next ledge. Pitch 4 (5.7, 4 bolts, 19m) Continue up through a few easy sections to the anchors. Pitch 5 (5.10a, 8 bolts, 23m) This pitch tends slightly to the right at the start then ends in a full out traverse to the anchors on the grassy mini ledge. Super fun slab pitch with great climbing! Optional Pitch 6 (5.11/5.12, 9 bolts, 30m) You can start this pitch one of two ways, as a link up with the first section of the last pitch, which makes for a more flowy line, or from the anchors atop pitch 5. Be cautious if you choose the latter as it creates bad rope drag and a higher fall potential at the start. The bolts on this pitch are in strange places and there seems to be two lines happening. The 30m accounts for a full send to the upper anchors as there are also bolts for an anchor halfway up (could use these to separate into two pitches). Also, there is currently an old white static help line attached to this pitch, don’t trust it… Descent: A single rope can descend this route, but having two ropes make it easier for longer and less frequent rappels, especially when descending pitch 5 as it contains a traverse section and is off to the side, but still possible with a single rope. NOTE: This line can be used to access the large tree ledge above (continue past the last anchor to a bomber tree), which in turn brings you to a whole different upper cliff band. Always wear a helmet! Bolted. Rap Hangers at each station as you rappel the route to get back down.

climbs.name: Rags to Riches
climbs.fa: Morgan Fines, Mark Guckert, David Relkoff, July 2015

content.description: Approach: (3 minutes) Walk diagonally across the first scree cone, following a faint trail, to reach the first ledge system. Carefully scramble to the right along the ledge, past a clump of trees and then farther along past a lone tree, to reach the first station with 2 bolt hangers. Pitch 1 (5.5, 2 bolts, 25m) Climb up and left to the 1st bolt, then scramble up easy terrain with loose scree for 15 m to reach the 2nd bolt. Go right and up to reach the bolted anchor. Pitch 2 (5.7, 3 bolts, 25m) Climb up through a section of 5.7 with 3 bolts and then scramble up the easy terrain with some loose scree up to the bolted anchor. Pitch 3 (5.6, 4 bolts, 29m) Use good route-finding (and good bolt spotting) to climb up past 4 bolts to reach the bolted anchor. Pitch 4 (5.8, 6 bolts, 29m) Climb up and left to reach the 1st bolt, then scramble up easy terrain, past the 2nd bolt to reach a 3rd bolt at a steeper wall. The 4th and 5th bolts protect the 5.8 crux move to reach the 6th bolt. Then carefully step up through some loose debris to reach the bolted anchor. Pitch 5 (5.6, 6 bolts, 33m) The Traverse Pitch! Traverse left along a narrow ledge past 4 bolts before heading up to a 5th bolt. Then scramble up the scree ledge to reach the 6th bolt directly above at the steep wall. Walk right and up along the base of the wall to a bolted belay BUT don’t stop here, keep going another 13m, up and right, on easy terrain, past one more bolt to another bolted belay. Pitch 6 (5.8, 8 bolts, 25m) The final stretch … Climb up past 8 bolts to reach the anchor. There are a couple of tricky moves … keep your eyes open and enjoy! Pitch 6a (5.11a, 9 bolts, 35m) The direct finish starts at the intermediate belay on Pitch 5. Take the line of bolts up from this belay for 5 bolts before it joins the original pitch 6 for the last 4 bolts. Let me know if you try this pitch out! Descent: Rappel the route with a single 60m rope. Then walk the ledge system back to the scree cone and down the trail to the parking lot. NOTE: Even though pitch 5 is listed as 33m (length of route you climb due to the traversing) you can still rappel directly from the pitch 5 anchor down to the pitch 4 anchor with a 60m rope. Be sure to tie knots in the ends of your rope!  Bolted. Rap Hangers at each station as you rappel the route to get back down.

25-30m bolts + gear. Head up the slippery orange rock towards the "chimney" this section is protected with bolts. Head into the "chimney" and start placing gear. Gear can be thin, be cautious of slinging blocks. This route could use some cleaning. Use the same anchor as Fools Gold. 



walk south from the parking lot through the trees up the scree slope. Start near the low point of the face on the orange rock.  

Bolts + Gear

Approach: (10 minutes) Walk along the old road, past the scree cone underneath the orange corner crack, to the far side of the scree cone where the trees reach down to the road. Take a faint trail up into the trees until you fixed the first fixed rope. Put your ascender on and start ascending the rope ...



At the moment (Summer 2020) you can ascend the fixed rope, traverse left along the fixed ropes (via ferrata style). Then ascend another rope and traverse some more to reach the upper treed ledge. Continue left through the trees until you reach the Lunch Log. For the Route Builders, this is an easy access up to the Upper Walls for more route development. But for most climbers, this would just be a descent option from the Upper Walls. In the Fall of 2020, we will need to remove the fixed ropes and we might set up some steel cabling in its place, but this is yet to be determined ...

Bolted. Fixed Ropes (11mm).

pathTokens: Emerald Lake - Multipitch from the ground up

content.description: North East facing cliff near Emerald Lake. Multi-Pitch Sport Routes. Perfect for hot summer days! Emerald Lake is a bit cool, but makes for a super refreshing swim after a great day of climbing!!
